siteMetadata.title: Autokin Automation
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using the Apollo GraphQL Client with React

frontmatter.title: Apollo Boost migration
frontmatter.description: Learn how to set up Apollo Client manually without Apollo Boost

children.value: Apollo Boost is a great way to get started with Apollo Client quickly, but there are some advanced features it doesn't support out of the box. If you'd like to use subscriptions, swap out the Apollo cache, or add an existing Apollo Link to your network stack that isn't already included, you will have to set Apollo Client up manually.
We're working on an eject feature for Apollo Boost that will make migration easier in the future, but for now, let's walk through how to migrate off of Apollo Boost.
If you're not using any configuration options on Apollo Boost, migration should be relatively simple. All you will have to change is the file where you initialize
Here's what client initialization looks like with Apollo Boost:
To create a basic client with the same defaults as Apollo Boost, first you need to install some packages:

is our recommended cache implementation for Apollo Client. The
is an Apollo Link that sends HTTP requests. Your network stack can be made up of one or more links, which you can chain together to create a customizable network stack. Learn more in our

If you are using configuration options on Apollo Boost, your migration path will vary depending on which ones you use. The next example will show an Apollo Boost client configured with every possible option.
Here's what client initialization looks like with Apollo Boost:
To create a client with the same defaults as Apollo Boost, first you need to install some packages:
apollo-client apollo-cache-inmemory apollo-link-http apollo-link apollo-link-state apollo-link-error --save
